history.content: I believe you can type "clear" and it will clear all breakpoints in debug mode (not in your actual code), and then you can run "c" to continue without stopping at breakpoints.

Hi all - random question unrelated to course advice...

We just learned in class how to use `pdb` and how to set breakpoints, but I can't seem to find a very basic function. Is there a "skip" that automatically skip all future breakpoints? 

Of course, we can spam "c" a million times, or even redefine the breaking function (see below). But ideally, there would be a way to type a command in the terminal and ignore all future breaks (without recompiling the code). I've tried looking for a solution online with little luck - so was wondering if anyone had any advice. Thanks!

pdb.set_trace = lambda *args: None
history.subject: PDB debugging
